attributes.Title: Gen Chem-Sci
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Chemistry
111
UMass Amherst
Basic principles of structure and reactivity. Microscopic nature of atoms and molecules; the macroscopic properties of chemical systems. Topics include stoichiometry, thermochemistry, atomic structure, molecular structure, properties of gases. (Gen.Ed. PS)
 
Prerequisites: MATH 101 and MATH 102, or its equivalent of  MATH 104, or a score of 20 or higher on Part "A" of the Math Placement test, or MATH 127, 128, 131, or 132.  Note: a maximum of 5 units may be received for both CHEM 101 and CHEM 102, or 2 units for either, if CHEM 111 is completed.
Math placemnt, 104, 127, 128,
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64061
Requisite: Prerequisites: MATH 101 and MATH 102, or its equivalent of  MATH 104, or a score of 20 or higher on Part "A" of the Math Placement test, or MATH 127, 128, 131, or 132.  Note: a maximum of 5 units may be received for both CHEM 101 and CHEM 102, or 2 units for either, if CHEM 111 is completed.

attributes.Title: ST-Nutrition Educ Practice
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
397B
UMass Amherst
This course exposes the learner to theoretical concepts, practical skills and approaches that are integral to nutrition education.  Students will be introduced to learning and communication styles, methods of conducting needs assessments in diverse environments and use of a framework for planning, designing, delivering and evaluating a nutrition education project.  Students will conduct regular nutrition education projects in the field outside of class time.
Pre Req: NUTRITN 230  Students must have either already taken or be concurrently enroll in NUTRITN 352.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Anatomy and Physiology II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Kinesiology
272
UMass Amherst
Study of structure and function of the following systems: endocrine, digestive, urinary, respiratory and cardiovascular systems. Integration and regulation of system function from an applied perspective through clinical applications.
Open to Kinesiology, Nutrition, Nursing, and Public Health majors only. KIN 270 w/ C-  Lab sections do not begin until the second week of classes.
This class is reserved for Kinesiology, Nutrition, Public Health and Nursing Majors Only.  If you cannot enroll but want to petition the Instructor for enrollment, please do the following: (1)  go to the Kinesiology Office, 110 Totman Building and pick up a "Course Overide Form"(2) Fill out the form, Attach unofficial transcrpt to the override form and leave them both in the Instructors mailbox, also located  in the 110 Totman
If your request is approved the course will be added to your schedule.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.

attributes.Title: Nutrition in the Life Cycle
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
352
UMass Amherst
Nutritional needs and effects of intakes during pregnancy and lactation, infancy, preschool period, middle childhood, adolescence, adulthood and aging. Relation of nutrition to physical and physiological growth, development, maturation, and decline. Prerequisites: NUTRITN 230, biochemistry, physiology.
Open to Senior and Junior Nutrition majors. NUTRITN 230 & KIN 272
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Nutrition/Healthy Lifestyle
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
130H
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the science of human nutrition. Relationship of health to food intake. Description, digestion, absorption, metabolism, interactions and functions of nutrients. Nutrient and energy requirements of young adults, athletes, older individuals. Nutrient deficiency symptoms. Body weight control. Eating disorders. Vegetarianism, other dietary preferences. Planning adequate diets that fit life-styles. Not for Nutrition majors.  (Gen.Ed. BS)
Open to Commonwealth College Freshman only
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

Spring
2016
Nutrition
497B

Description not available at this time
Open to HANDS Scholars Only.   {HANDS, Health and Nutrition Diversity Scholars, is a multicultural professional development program designed to increase the diversity of those who pursue nutrition as a major and to prepare nutrition majors to work with diverse populations.  For further information and application, visit www.umass.edu/sphhs/hands.  While this program is open to all nutrition majors, students of those population groups currently underrepresented in nutrition (i.e., African Americans, Hispanics, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or other Pacific Islanders) are encouraged to apply.  Applications are accepted on a rolling admissions basis.}
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Organic Chemistry
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Chemistry
250
UMass Amherst
A one-semester introduction to chemistry of organic compounds: alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, aromatic compounds, alkyl halides, alcohols, ethers, aldehydes and ketones, carboxylic acids and their derivatives, phenols, amines, fats, amino acids, carbohydrates. Emphasizes nomenclature, structure, synthesis, stereochemistry, mechanisms of organic reactions.  Prerequisite: CHEM 110 or 111 or equivalent.
Pre Req: CHEM 110 or 111 w/C-
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64134
Requisite: A one-semester introduction to chemistry of organic compounds: alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, aromatic compounds, alkyl halides, alcohols, ethers, aldehydes and ketones, carboxylic acids and their derivatives, phenols, amines, fats, amino acids, carbohydrates. Emphasizes nomenclature, structure, synthesis, stereochemistry, mechanisms of organic reactions.  Prerequisite: CHEM 110 or 111 or equivalent.

attributes.Title: ST-Nutritional Genomics
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
597J
UMass Amherst
This course will provide a broad introductory overview of the molecular mechanisms of diet-induced changes in gene expression and the modulatory role of genetic polymorphisms, but will primarily be focused on group discussion of illustrative primary genomics research papers relevant to the development of disease or the response to various environmental exposures.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: FYS - First Year Seminar
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
191NUTR1
UMass Amherst
This seminar is based on gene expression being influenced by our choices-what we eat, physical activity, environment, and overall lifestyle.  It is fascinating how we can choose to live well by modifying our intake or activities and in turn controlling the expression of genes that are directly related to obesity, diabetes, CVD, and cancer.  I believe this seminar would be a great way of introducing the incoming freshmen to the possibilities that lie ahead in terms of both prevention and cure of significant disease conditions leading towards a much healthier lifestyle through simple day to day modifications.
Open to freshmen in the following majors: Public Health, Communication Disorders, Kinesiology, and Nutrition.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
40791

attributes.Title: Prac Skills in Nutrtn Counslng
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
585
UMass Amherst
Knowledge of dietary treatment of diseases (Medical Nutrition Therapy) applied in simulated one-on-one counseling settings.  Topics include: interviewing/listening skills, assessing readiness, developing care plans, multicultural counseling, computerized diet analysis.
Open to Undergraduate Seniors only. PreReq:NUTR 352 & 480
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
66538

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
140

Open to Connect PHHS and Foundations RAP students in Crabtree Hall.

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
140H
UMass Amherst
Explores the complex interactions between nutrition and fitness in humans.
To this end, we will examine the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, sports nutrition, obesity and weight management, eating disorders, and diets such as vegan and vegetarianism as they relate to fitness and health.
Open to Commonwealth College students only.

attributes.Title: Basic Nutrition
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
230
UMass Amherst
Basic principles of human nutrition. Energy needs. Chemical structures, physical characteristics, and metabolism of protein, carbohydrate, lipids, minerals, and vitamins. Human requirements at various ages. Food sources. Effects of deficiency or excess on health. Prerequisites: general biology and chemistry; organic chemistry concurrent.
Open to Nutrition Majors Only. NUTRITN 130 & CHEM 112,122,102  Previous or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 250 or CHEM 262 is required. Nutrition students concurrently taking NUTRITN 130 may also enroll.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Nutrition
640

(Prerequisites: NUTRITN 572 and 577, or consent of instructor)
Pre Req: NUTRITN 572 & 577

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
741
UMass Amherst

(Prerequisite:  BIOST&EP 540)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Nutrition
678
UMass Amherst
Causes and consequences of malnutrition in developing countries from an interdisciplinary viewpoint. Some knowledge of agriculture nutrition and/or health sciences required. Student presentations and discussion of current issues pertaining to nutrition and development. Prerequisite: NUTRITN 578 or consent of instructor.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Medical Nutritn Therapy
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Nutrition
580
UMass Amherst
Physiological and metabolic bases for nutritional care and the application of this knowledge to the treatment of specific diseases.  Topics include: surgery, burns, infections, cancer, liver diseases, renal failure, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and alternative modes of feeding.  Also includes application of nutrition knowledge to specific diseases and problems encountered in the practice of clinical dietetics (medical nutrition therapy).  
Prerequisites: NUTRITN 352 or 430, or KIN 585
This course is open to Nutrition seniors and Nutrition graduate students only. Nutritn 230,480 & KIN 272
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
36578

attributes.Title: SciFoodPrinciples&MealPlanning
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
210
UMass Amherst
With lab. Meal management; emphasis on nutritional, economic, time, ethnic, and cultural factors. Experimental application of the chemical and physical properties of food in food preparation.
Open to senior, junior, and sophomore Nutrition majors only. CHEM 111, NUTRITN 230
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
66513

attributes.Title: Nutrition Problems in US
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
577
UMass Amherst
This class is designed to help you reflect and integrate what you have learned from your nutrition coursework as well as that from your Gen Ed courses and other experiences that have contributed to your development on the way to your final year at UMass. The goal of this course is for students to develop insight into the epidemiologic, physiologic, biochemical and nutritional complexities of major diet-related diseases in the United States. It satisfies the Integrated Experience requirement for BS-Nutrition majors.
Open to senior and junior Nutrition majors. NUTRITN230,KIN272,STAT111,etc.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
70897
66525

attributes.Title: ST- Nutritn,Food,PhysActvy...
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
597S
UMass Amherst
This course will explore the relationship between nutrition, food and lifestyle with the development of cancer.  Topics will include: international variations and trends of cancer; introduction of basic concepts and principles of the cancer process; evidence for physical activity (including body fatness) and cancer prevention; dietary and lifestyle recommendations for cancer prevention.  The goal of this course is for students to develop insight into dietary and lifestyle strategies for cancer prevention.
Open to Seniors, Juniors and Graduate students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
66571

attributes.Title: Nutrition/Healthy Lifestyle
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
130
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the science of human nutrition and the relationship of food and nutrients to health and disease. Topics covered include digestion, and functions of macro and micro nutrients as well as current recommendations for nutrient intake. We will also discuss energy balance and weight control. (Gen.Ed. BS)
Introduction to the science of human nutrition and the relationship of food and nutrients to health and disease. Topics covered include digestion, and functions of macro and micro nutrients as well as current recommendations for nutrient intake. We will also discuss energy balance and weight control. Nutrition majors should, if possible, enroll in Nutrition Section 130 Section 2. Nursing majors should, if possible enroll in Nutrition130 Section D

UMass Amherst
Skills and techniques needed to effectively carry out community nutrition programs and nutrition education, including knowledge of agencies and programs, community assessment, legislation, nutrition education, and working with people.
Pre Req: NUTRITN 352
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
66523

attributes.Title: Organic Chemistry
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Chemistry
262
UMass Amherst
Organic Chemistry II for Non Majors. Together with CHEM 261 satisfies requirements for medical school admissions. Acceptable, with approval of the Undergraduate Chemistry Adviser, though not recommended, for chemistry majors. Brief review of basic principles of chemical bonding, electronic theory, and acid-base reactions. Introduction to principles of stereochemistry and organic spectroscopy. Discussions of the most common types of reactions of organic molecules and their mechanisms.
Pre Req: CHEM 261 or 265 w/C-
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64080

attributes.Title: ST-Culture, Nutrition & Health
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Nutrition
597K
UMass Amherst
How culture and ethnicity affect dietary practices and health in the U.S.  Influence of food security, acculturation, and politics on food availability, food practices, and health outcomes.  Health and health disparities in different cultural/ethnic groups, including overview of epigenetics.  Emphasis on cross-cultural communication to address health and nutrition concerns.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
